AMI.name: Agent Maturity Index
AMI.description: Measures how production-ready an agent framework/system is across 6 weighted dimensions.

dimensions.name: Reliability
dimensions.description: Uptime, error handling, recovery from failures, consistent output quality

dimensions.name: Observability
dimensions.description: Logging, tracing, debugging tools, execution visibility

dimensions.name: Tooling Ecosystem
dimensions.description: Available integrations, plugins, MCP servers, third-party tools

dimensions.name: Security Posture
dimensions.description: Vulnerability count, CVEs, audit results, secure defaults

dimensions.name: Execution Control
dimensions.description: Permission models, sandboxing, human-in-the-loop, approval gates

dimensions.name: Deployment Maturity
dimensions.description: CI/CD support, containerization, scaling options, enterprise readiness

ARI.name: Autonomy Risk Index
ARI.description: Measures risk exposure when running a system autonomously. Higher = more risk.

dimensions.name: Permission Model Strength
dimensions.description: Granularity and enforcement of tool/resource permissions

dimensions.name: Sandboxing / Isolation
dimensions.description: Container isolation, network segmentation, filesystem boundaries

dimensions.name: Default Network Exposure
dimensions.description: Whether the system exposes ports, accepts inbound connections by default

dimensions.name: Secret Handling
dimensions.description: API key storage, credential rotation, encrypted config

dimensions.name: Human-in-the-Loop Controls
dimensions.description: Approval gates, confirmation dialogs, review checkpoints

dimensions.name: Audit Logging
dimensions.description: Execution logs, change tracking, forensic capability

EPI.name: Ecosystem Power Index
EPI.description: Measures distribution strength, community gravity, and ecosystem reach.

dimensions.name: Adoption Signals
dimensions.description: GitHub stars, npm downloads, Docker pulls, community size

dimensions.name: Vendor Integration Breadth
dimensions.description: Number of platforms, IDEs, and services with native support

dimensions.name: Enterprise Penetration
dimensions.description: Known enterprise deployments, SOC2 compliance, support contracts

dimensions.name: Standard Alignment
dimensions.description: MCP support, OpenAPI compliance, protocol adherence

dimensions.name: Release Velocity
dimensions.description: Commit frequency, release cadence, maintainer activity

frameworks.name: OpenClaw
frameworks.description: Open-source AI agent framework. Formerly aligned with creator, now independent foundation with OpenAI backing.

Reliability.note: Rapid adoption but immature error handling reported

Observability.note: Built-in logging, web dashboard, execution traces

Tooling Ecosystem.note: 185K stars, large contributor base, multi-LLM support

Execution Control.note: Basic approval modes exist but defaults are permissive

Deployment Maturity.note: Docker support, cloud deployment options, but no enterprise SLA

Permission Model Strength.note: Defaults allow full filesystem + network access

Secret Handling.note: API keys stored in plaintext config by default

Human-in-the-Loop Controls.note: Optional approval mode, but auto-run is default

Audit Logging.note: Basic logs, no tamper-proof audit trail

topRiskDrivers: 40,214 instances publicly exposed on the internet with default credentials
512 known vulnerabilities with 3 published CVEs as of January 2026
Permissive defaults: auto-run mode enabled, full filesystem access granted by default
mitigations: Never expose to public internet — run behind VPN/firewall
Enable approval mode for all destructive operations
Run inside Docker container with limited filesystem mounts

Adoption Signals.note: 185K GitHub stars in 6 weeks — fastest agent adoption recorded

Vendor Integration Breadth.note: Multi-LLM, VS Code extension, browser-based interface

Enterprise Penetration.note: Growing but limited by security concerns

Release Velocity.note: Daily commits, rapid iteration, large contributor pool

frameworks.name: LangChain
frameworks.description: Comprehensive LLM application framework. Most established agent orchestration toolkit with LangGraph for stateful agents.

Reliability.note: Battle-tested in production, LangSmith for monitoring

Observability.note: LangSmith tracing, LangFuse integration, detailed logs

Security Posture.note: Better than OpenClaw but prompt injection risks remain

Deployment Maturity.note: LangServe for deployment, Docker support, cloud options

Permission Model Strength.note: Tool-level permissions configurable but not enforced by default

Sandboxing / Isolation.note: No built-in sandboxing, relies on deployment environment

Secret Handling.note: Environment variable based, no encrypted store

topRiskDrivers: No built-in sandboxing — relies entirely on deployment environment for isolation
Prompt injection vectors in complex chain compositions
Secret management via environment variables without rotation
mitigations: Use LangGraph checkpoints for review before critical actions
Deploy with container isolation and network policies
Enable LangSmith tracing for full execution auditability

Adoption Signals.note: 100K GitHub stars, largest community in agent space

Enterprise Penetration.note: Wide enterprise use, LangChain Inc. offers support

frameworks.name: n8n / Make
frameworks.description: Visual workflow automation platforms with growing AI agent capabilities. No-code/low-code approach.

Observability.note: Visual execution logs, workflow history, error tracking

Security Posture.note: Self-hosted option, credential encryption, but agent-specific security minimal

Execution Control.note: Workflow-level control, but limited agent-specific gates

Deployment Maturity.note: Docker, cloud, Kubernetes support, enterprise tier

Sandboxing / Isolation.note: Node isolation within workflows, but limited OS-level sandboxing

Default Network Exposure.note: Webhook exposure, but behind auth by default

Secret Handling.note: Encrypted credential store, separate from workflow data

Human-in-the-Loop Controls.note: Manual trigger nodes, approval workflows possible

Audit Logging.note: Execution history, but no tamper-proof audit trail

topRiskDrivers: Webhook endpoints can be exposed if misconfigured
Agent nodes may execute with broader permissions than intended
Credential store encryption relies on deployment configuration
mitigations: Use self-hosted deployment behind firewall
Enable webhook authentication on all endpoints
Regularly audit credential access and workflow permissions

Adoption Signals.note: n8n: 50K+ stars, Make: millions of users

Enterprise Penetration.note: Enterprise tiers, SOC2, growing B2B adoption

frameworks.name: Clawdia
frameworks.description: Desktop-native autonomous AI workspace. Anthropic-optimized, local-first execution environment with full OS-level integration.

Observability.note: Conversation history, tool activity logging, but no dashboard

Tooling Ecosystem.note: Browser, shell, file, process tools built-in; no plugin marketplace

Security Posture.note: Encrypted config, local-only execution, no network exposure

Execution Control.note: Approval modes, tool-level permissions, task scheduling gates

Deployment Maturity.note: Desktop-only, no cloud deployment, requires Electron + Node.js

Permission Model Strength.note: Tool-level permissions, approval gates per operation type

Sandboxing / Isolation.note: Local-only execution, no inbound network, OS-level process isolation

Default Network Exposure.note: Zero listening ports, zero inbound connections, desktop app only

Secret Handling.note: electron-store encrypted config, API keys never transmitted except to Anthropic

Human-in-the-Loop Controls.note: Approval modes configurable, task execution review available

Audit Logging.note: Full conversation history, tool call logging, but no export/SIEM integration

topRiskDrivers: Full OS-level access means a compromised agent could affect the entire system
Single-developer maintenance — bus factor risk for security patches
No formal security audit or third-party penetration testing
mitigations: Run on a dedicated machine or VM for high-risk tasks
Review tool call logs regularly via conversation history
Use approval mode for destructive operations (file delete, shell exec)

Adoption Signals.note: 1 GitHub star, single developer — pre-community stage

Enterprise Penetration.note: No enterprise deployments, no support tier

Standard Alignment.note: No MCP server, but consumes Anthropic tool-use protocol

Release Velocity.note: Active single-developer commits, but low frequency

frameworks.name: AutoGen
frameworks.description: Microsoft Research multi-agent framework. Enables conversational multi-agent systems with role-based collaboration.

Observability.note: Agent conversation logs, but limited dashboard tooling

Tooling Ecosystem.note: 40K stars, growing integration set, Azure ecosystem

Security Posture.note: Better defaults than OpenClaw, but limited formal audits

Deployment Maturity.note: Azure integration, Docker support, enterprise path via Microsoft

Permission Model Strength.note: Agent-level role definitions with code execution controls

Audit Logging.note: Conversation logs, but no formal audit system

topRiskDrivers: Code execution agent can run arbitrary code without sandboxing by default
Multi-agent conversations can escalate permissions across agents
No built-in credential management system
mitigations: Enable Docker-based code execution for isolation
Implement strict role boundaries between agents
Monitor agent conversations for unexpected tool escalation

Vendor Integration Breadth.note: Azure ecosystem, multi-LLM, but fewer third-party integrations

Release Velocity.note: Regular releases from Microsoft Research team

frameworks.name: CrewAI
frameworks.description: Role-based multi-agent framework. Enables team-of-agents approach with specialized roles and task delegation.

Reliability.note: Growing adoption, but less battle-tested than LangChain

Observability.note: Task output logging, but limited tracing tools

Security Posture.note: No formal security audit, standard web security practices

Execution Control.note: Role-based task delegation, but limited granular control

Deployment Maturity.note: Python package, Docker support, early enterprise features

Permission Model Strength.note: Role-based access, but agents share tool access broadly

Sandboxing / Isolation.note: No built-in sandboxing beyond Python process boundaries

Human-in-the-Loop Controls.note: Possible but not default — agents run autonomously

Audit Logging.note: Task completion logs, limited forensic capability

topRiskDrivers: Multi-agent role delegation can lead to unintended permission escalation
No sandboxing — agents run in shared Python environment
Default autonomous execution without human review gates
mitigations: Define explicit tool allowlists per agent role
Implement review gates between agent task handoffs
Run in containerized environment with restricted system access

Enterprise Penetration.note: Early enterprise adoption, CrewAI Enterprise tier

frameworks.name: Vercel AI SDK
frameworks.description: TypeScript SDK for building AI applications with streaming UI. Strong Next.js integration for product-facing agents.

Observability.note: Streaming callbacks, but limited agent-specific tracing

Tooling Ecosystem.note: All major LLM providers, Next.js/React integration

Security Posture.note: Server-side execution, standard web security, Vercel security model

Execution Control.note: Tool definitions with schema validation, but limited agent control

Permission Model Strength.note: Server-side tool execution with schema validation

Sandboxing / Isolation.note: Serverless function isolation via Vercel platform

Default Network Exposure.note: API endpoints exposed, but server-side only

Human-in-the-Loop Controls.note: Streaming UI enables real-time user interaction

Audit Logging.note: Vercel logs, but no agent-specific audit trail

topRiskDrivers: Serverless execution limits long-running agent tasks
Tool execution on server side shares function context
No built-in agent-specific audit logging
mitigations: Use Vercel's built-in security features for API protection
Implement tool-level rate limiting and validation
Add custom logging middleware for agent action tracking

Vendor Integration Breadth.note: All major LLM providers, strong React/Next.js integration

frameworks.name: OpenAI Agents SDK
frameworks.description: OpenAI's first-party agent SDK. Native integration with GPT models, Operator, and OpenAI platform services.

Reliability.note: OpenAI infrastructure backing, but newer SDK

Observability.note: OpenAI dashboard, but agent tracing is early

Tooling Ecosystem.note: GPT Actions, function calling, Operator integration

Execution Control.note: Function calling boundaries, but limited fine-grained control

Deployment Maturity.note: Cloud-native via OpenAI platform, limited self-hosting

Permission Model Strength.note: Function-level permissions, but OpenAI controls execution environment

Sandboxing / Isolation.note: Cloud-side execution isolation via OpenAI infrastructure

Default Network Exposure.note: Cloud API — data leaves your infrastructure

Secret Handling.note: OpenAI manages keys, but all data transits OpenAI servers

Audit Logging.note: OpenAI API logs, but limited self-service export

topRiskDrivers: All data and execution transits OpenAI cloud infrastructure
Limited control over execution environment and data retention
Vendor lock-in to OpenAI ecosystem and pricing
mitigations: Use function calling with strict schema validation
Implement client-side logging for audit independence
Design for portability — abstract OpenAI-specific calls

Adoption Signals.note: 15K GitHub stars, growing OpenAI developer community

Standard Alignment.note: OpenAI function calling standard, limited interop

frameworks.name: Semantic Kernel
frameworks.description: Microsoft's enterprise AI orchestration SDK. Designed for C#/.NET and Python enterprise applications with Azure integration.

Security Posture.note: Azure AD integration, enterprise security model

Permission Model Strength.note: Plugin permission system, Azure AD integration

Human-in-the-Loop Controls.note: Plugin approval flows, but not default

topRiskDrivers: Enterprise complexity can mask misconfigurations
Azure dependency creates cloud lock-in risk
Plugin system permissions require careful configuration
mitigations: Leverage Azure AD for plugin-level authorization
Enable Azure Monitor for full execution tracing
Use Azure Key Vault for all credential management

Enterprise Penetration.note: Microsoft enterprise channel, existing Azure customers

Standard Alignment.note: OpenAI API compatible, Azure standard protocols
